adjective.description: Psychology and Philosophy. Relating to or involving a subject's apprehension of objects or events (which may or may not involve cognition); designating or relating to the interaction that exists between a subject and an entity or event.

origin: Mid 19th century; earliest use found in Isaac Taylor (1787–1865), writer on theology, artist, and inventor. From classical Latin prehēns-, past participial stem of prehendere prehend + -ive.
